column2:
COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country.
Document checklist
1. Passenger Locator Form.
2. Proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative COVID-19 test result.
3. Travellers who are not vaccinated or recovered must present either a PCR test no older than 48 hours, or an antigen test no older than 24 hours.
4. Travellers who cannot provide at least one document must self-isolate on arrival for seven days. Quarantine ends when they can provide a negative PCR test result from the fifth day.
Entry rules: Children younger than 12 years are exempt from quarantine and testing requirements.
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation.
All travellers are required to complete a Passenger Locator Form. Travellers who cannot produce at least one document at the border must self-isolate for seven days. Quarantine ends when they can provide a negative PCR test from the fifth day of home quarantine. Children younger than 12 years are exempt from quarantine and testing requirements.
column4:
Proof of vaccination against COVID-19 as follows:
A 2nd dose of Pfizer/BioNtech
A 2nd dose of Moderna
A first dose of AstraZeneca
A dose of Janssen by Johnson & Johnson / Jansse-Cilag
A 1st dose of Covishield by the Serum Institute of India / AstraZeneca
A 2nd dose of Sputnik V
A 2nd dose of Coronavac from Sinovac Biotech
A 2nd dose of the COVID-19 vaccine produced by Sinopharm
A combination of two of the vaccines listed above.
column5:
Latest News:

International Restrictions:
*From within the EU:

Documents equivalent to the 'EU Digital COVID Certificate' are also accepted, if they meet the requirements listed above for the EUDCC.

All travellers are required to complete a Passenger Locator Form.

Travellers not vaccinated or recovered must present either a PCR test no older than 48 hours, or an antigen test no older than 24 hours. Travellers who cannot produce at least one document at the border must self-isolate for seven days. Quarantine ends when they can provide a negative PCR test from the fifth day of home quarantine.

Children younger than 12 years are exempt from quarantine and testing requirements.

Learn more:

Ministry of the Interior

Tourism Portal


Documents you need to travel in Europe
Health cover for temporary stays
*Transit:

Persons entering Slovenia in transit must have with them:

  • Valid travel document (including a visa or a residence permit when required)
  • A document on the purpose and destination of transit (as of 14 July 2020 this document is not required for travellers with a permanent or temporary residence in EU member states)

Entry to Slovenia shall be denied to persons for whom it is foreseen that they may not be able to exit Slovenia due to measures in neighbouring countries.

A person may enter Slovenia without any restrictions and the need to quarantine if he or she is to transit Slovenia within a 12-hour period.Transit within the 6-hour period applies to persons who are under quarantine orders issued by other states on account of their exposure to a person infected with Covid-19, who wish to spend their quarantine in another state and do not show any signs of infection.

This means that passengers must exit Slovenia within this period and must travel through Slovenia without making unnecessary or redundant stops or leaving the main transit route. While transiting, passengers may attend to necessary things such as fill up the gas tank, stop for physiological needs (drink, food, toilet, etc.), but may not stay overnight.

Find out more:
Policija - Transit through Slovenia on way to another country - clarification


*From Third Countries:

Entry rules

Travellers must provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result. Details are listed below. Travellers who cannot produce at least one document at the border must self-isolate for seven days. Quarantine ends when they can provide a negative PCR test from the fifth day of home quarantine.

Mandatory travel documents

1. Passenger Locator Form.

2. Proof of vaccination. Approved vaccines: BioNtech/Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson/Janssen, AstraZeneca, Sputnik V and Sinovac.

3. Proof of recovery. Travellers must provide a positive PCR test older than 10 days but not older than six months (180 days). Alternately, they must provide a medical certificate to prove that no more than six months have passed since the onset of symptoms. Certificates are accepted from these countries.

4. Travellers not vaccinated or recovered must present either a PCR test no older than 48 hours, or an antigen test no older than 24 hours. Travellers should consult the types of tests and the countries from which they are accepted. 

Children younger than 12 years are exempt from quarantine and testing requirements.

Learn more:

Ministry of the Interior

Tourism Portal



Internal Restrictions:
*Moving around in Slovenia: Movement between all statistical regions is permitted.
*Public spaces and further measures: A surgical mask or FFP2 type mask must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, on public transport, in open places and outside where a distance of 1.5 metres cannot be maintained and in private vehicles when travelling with members of other households for work purposes.
Fabric masks are no longer permitted.
Face masks are not compulsory for children under the age of six, primary school pupils up to 5th grade when in classrooms, and people practicing non-contact sports, if a distance of 3 metres can be maintained.
Many of the rules apply across all of Slovenia, but some rules are specific to regions depending on their Covid-rating. You can find the status of a specific statistical region on the Slovenian Government website.
Unless stated elsewhere, the rules below apply to all of Slovenia. Further details can be found on the Slovene government website • All businesses, establishments and services (including shops, restaurants, bars and public transport) are required to ensure their staff and customers (including children aged 12 years and above) meet one of the following criteria: are fully vaccinated, have a negative COVID-19 test, or have evidence of recovery from COVID-19 in the last 180 days. When travelling in Slovenia you will see this requirement signposted in many establishments as ‘PCT’ You should expect to be asked to show evidence that you meet one of these requirements, together with a valid identity document, before accessing a service, including when seated outdoors. The only exceptions to this requirement are: emergency departments in hospitals; COVID testing and COVID and flu vaccine centres; grocery stores and pharmacies that are not located inside shopping malls; and charities providing urgent support. In grocery stores and pharmacies you should expect social distancing measures of 10 square metres per customer to be in place, and a sign at the entrance showing the maximum number of people that are allowed inside
• Slovenia will accept the proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
If you hold a Slovenian health card, rapid antigen tests are available free of charge at test centres. If you do not hold a Slovenian health card, you should expect to pay for a test. See the list of test centres • Restaurants and bars are allowed to open between 5am and 10pm, and are only allowed to provide a seated service (indoors or outdoors). Signs should be displayed at the entrance showing the maximum number of customers allowed. Customers who are 12 years old and over should expect to be asked to provide evidence of a negative test, or proof of COVID-19 recovery in the last 180 days, or vaccination, together with a valid identity document
• Nightclubs, bars and restaurants that offer entertainment (music or dance) are not allowed to open
• Takeaway services are open and permitted
• Hotels are allowed to open. Hotel guests who are aged 12 years and older are required to provide evidence of a negative test, or proof of COVID-19 recovery in the last 180 days, or a vaccination
• Public sports events are allowed where fixed seating is provided and where every other seat can be left vacant. The use of surgical or FFP2 face mask is mandatory, and all participants must show proof of their COVID recovered/vaccinated/tested status together with valid identification
• All education establishments continue to deliver classes in person. From 15 November 2021, schools will conduct rapid antigen self-testing on all students three times a week
• Indoor and outdoor sports facilities are open. You will be required to meet PCT rules
• Visits to care homes and hospitals are by appointment only. You should contact the care home or hospital you wish to visit for full details of visiting options, noting that these options are subject to short notice change
• All services within Slovenian public administration offices are by appointment only
• You should not attend hospitals or dental clinics for non-essential reasons, unless you have an appointment
• All libraries, museums and galleries are open. Indoor culture facilities are allowed to operate up to a limited capacity, which will be displayed at the entrance. To access facilities customers are required to show evidence of a negative COVID test, recovery, or vaccination along with a valid identity document. A surgical/FFP2 face mask should be worn
• Religious gatherings are allowed where a distance of 1.5 metres can be observed between people. Participants are required to show evidence of a negative COVID test, recovery, or vaccination, along with an identity document. A surgical/FFP2 face mask needs to be worn
• Public cultural events in open public spaces are not allowed, but are permitted in enclosed public spaces with fixed seating, where every other seat can be left vacant. The use of surgical or FFP2 face masks is mandatory, and all participants must show evidence of a negative COVID test, recovery, or vaccination along with a valid identity document
• All other public events, public gatherings, celebrations, and wedding ceremonies are temporarily prohibited and are only allowed for groups of people who are immediate family members or share the same household
The Slovene government provides English-language coronavirus guidance and updates. *If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
